text: [Music]
hi my name is Krista Germano
I'm the senior marketing communications
manager for AWS worldwide public sector
and I'm joined here today with Mike
Davis Mike Davis is a storage business
development manager for AWS thanks for
coming and the topic we're going to talk
about today is digital preservation and
archiving so let's get started
oftentimes when we think about storage
we think about backup and recovery well
where does archiving and digital
preservation fit in right
great question archiving and digital
preservation there's really three main
differences from traditional backup the
first might be that these assets are
these files this data has really
intrinsic value to these institutions
it's not just there for disaster
recovery and so the value could be in
the form of historical value it could be
in the form of even the licensing value
could be revenue-generating digital
assets another main difference from
backup is that these assets are retained
in some cases for very long periods of
time our customer the National Archives
has a policy that they will retain these
assets for the life of the Republic and
imagine how long that is
and thirdly this is a primary storage
these are not secondary copies of the
assets and so they're very concerned
about durability in the infrastructure
and with the evolving technology space
with cloud computing what does that mean
for the role of the archivist well it's
a there are a lot of things that have
been changing over the last few years in
particular digital has really become
central central part of the archivists
job even archivists that come from the
library space or managing physical
museums digital is now so important to
them because the number of artifacts
that can be collected and shared and
viewed by the stakeholders really
proliferate s-- at that point now these
a lot of interesting challenges here one
of the
is managing IT infrastructure digital
preservationist shouldn't have to worry
about being IT leaders and their they
shouldn't have to worry about the
scalability challenges of this sort of
these born-digital data streams and so
forth another challenge that they have
when the number of digital assets really
proliferate s--
is a challenge around taxonomy and
search how do I find something when now
I'm managing a hundred million assets in
my collection and so become so important
to to manage metadata and to create as
much context around these assets as you
can so you mentioned some of the
challenges how does AWS help with
archiving and digital preservation sure
AWS is working with a lot of these
customers right now moving their
collections into into our infrastructure
and a lot of times it's coming from
example tape based archives which have
lots of management challenges
scalability challenges quality and
durability challenge challenges and that
data often is coming in through our s3
API and eventually landing and glacier
and what we're able to provide to these
customers is so much better scalability
and we take a lot of the risks in the
operational challenges off the table
when they move their assets into us but
one of the most important things the
thing we see recurring again and again
is these customers are seeing the
ability to extract more value from their
assets and to create richer context and
metadata here using AWS analytics
capabilities and so a lot of times when
we approach these customers we start
with the conversation about what you can
do with your assets once they're in the
cloud using automatic transcription
transcribing speech-to-text facial
recognition and these kinds of
capabilities to allow them to do better
job as archivists and provide a richer
experience for their end users who are
getting access to these assets and can
you share a couple customer examples
from public sector of how they're using
the AWS cloud for archiving and digital
preservation sure in fact I just came
over from a conference led by the White
House Historical Association who is a
a big customer of ours a much larger
public-sector customer would be the
national archives they're working with
us on these workflows and and these
archival solutions another example in
the public sector in a slightly
different space is is NASA and you can
imagine across the science community the
need to retain lots of data for decades
and decades for historical analysis for
example for climate change and these
researchers are very keen to properly
archive and manage and what's great in
my role is I can see these patterns
repeat in other areas like the
commercial sectors Fox Pictures for
example is doing archival on us and you
can imagine the film studios with deep
and rich archives well having some of
the same problems as well as
broadcasters like Turner Broadcasting so
we've been very successful in this space
because of the value proposition we've
been able to offer both at the storage
layer as well as in analytics and
insight and context for around metadata
alright thanks Mike for sharing a little
bit about digital preservation and
